Summary I started working on computers in 1984 when personal computers were still relatively new devices and modems were the means to remote access. I joined IBM x86 team in 1995 and remained there until the division was sold to Lenovo in October 2014. With 20 years of experience, I've worked at nearly every level of storage hardware introduction to include to support, engineering and new product development. I've worked directly with customers on diverse issues and I can bring that experience forward to new solutions and products. 
 
In today's era of innovation coming from all directions, the data center is changing, but how do you sort through the edge technology to find the components that provide stability, reliability, performance, manageability with the right feature set? In my previous roles, I worked with a variety of leading vendors in enterprise storage technology and learned the right questions to ask and how to properly evaluate each of these attributes. 
 
Professional Experience: 
• Enterprise PCIe Flash Storage Solutions based on Fusion-io/SanDisk and many others. 
• Enterprise Memory-Channel-Storage Devices, eXFlash DDR3 Storage DIMM. 
• Enterprise Storage RAID Technologies based on LSI, PMC/Adaptec RAID stacks. 
• General server expertise with advanced knowledge and skills on nearly every subsystem. 
• IOP & IOC RAID Adapters or ROMB, and Driver-based RAID and OS-based RAID. 
• Storage Devices Based on PCIe, SCSI, SAS, SATA, Fibre Channel, NAS. 
• Storage subsystem software integration development and test planning/execution. 
• Network Operating systems: Windows and Linux (RHEL, SLES, Debian distro's, +),  
installation, configuration, testing, Bash and Powershell scripting and debug. 
• Lecroy Protocol and Logic Analyzers.

Experience SanDisk Enterprise Technical Support L3 SanDisk March 2015  – Present (6 months) Greater Salt Lake City Area Solid State Storage Device Engineer Lenovo October 2014  –  January 2015  (4 months) Morrisville, NC In this position I was the lead System x Storage Device Engineer for eXFlash DIMM DDR3 memory-channel-storage and PCIe SSD's adapters based on SanDisk technologies. This required vendor integration into Lenovo servers for uEFI support, new management functions, automated thermal controls, new power dynamics, performance and testing for a variety of operating systems. System x Storage Development IBM June 2008  –  September 2014  (6 years 4 months) Raleigh-Durham, North Carolina Area In this position as an IBM System x storage development engineer, I was responsible for testing and validating the software for the various storage devices within my projects to ensure they operate as define by IBM requirements and delivered to the business on schedule. There is a strong focus on quality and a continuity of the customer experience as products change or improve with each generation. I was responsible for delivering IBM's first and second generation of High IOPS flash storage controllers. In other roles I investigate defects found in test cycles across the ServeRAID family of storage adapters and help bring them to a resolution. As a technical author, I've written many published documents defining best practices, problem determination guides, and many knowledge base tips. I've been a major contributor for defining features and behavioral specification for the RAID series products. As development engineer, I always engage, assist and transfer skills to our support structure as needed. IBM Product Engineer for ServeRAID and Storage Adapters IBM October 2005  –  June 2008  (2 years 9 months) Raleigh-Durham, North Carolina Area During this period of time, I specialized in IBM's storage subsystems for the ServeRAID Product Engineering team supporting warranty issues on all IBM RAID products for the System x brand, and the older xSeries, Netfinity and PC Server platforms. My focus was all SCSI, SAS, and SATA, controllers branded for IBM by OEM RAID vendors including Adaptec and LSI. This is the highest technical escalation point within IBM System x and all customer situations are owned by this team (within their specialty) until they come to a conclusion. I became known worldwide within IBM as a leading expert on IBM RAID controller and have written hundreds of pages of documentation, tips, procedures, instructions, white papers on all aspects of installing, maintaining and diagnosing problems within IBM System x storage offerings. IBM World Wide Level-2 (Back office) IBM July 2000  –  October 2005  (5 years 4 months) Raleigh-Durham, North Carolina Area The World Wide Level-2 organization within IBM is the primary escalation point for all server warranty issues from IBM Support Centers in every major geographic location around the world, to include U.S., Europe, Canada, South America, Africa, Japan, China and others. I continued to focus on IBM enterprise hardware and IBM RAID storage subsystems and eventually became the focal point for the WWL2 team in these area. The escalations handled were typically situations where multiple action plans had failed to resolve the matter and either specialized skills or advance debugging was necessary to isolate a defect or correct the issues. Occasionally, it was required to travel to customer locations to investigate problems directly, or to provide education and skills transfer to geo support technicians. Lead Product Specialist – Enterprise Servers IBM November 1998  –  July 2000  (1 year 9 months) Raleigh-Durham, North Carolina Area As a Lead Product Specialist, I directly supported a large group of level-1 remote technical support specialists in the IBM HelpCenter with advanced and creative troubleshooting. Deep hardware and network operating system skills were required to complement new and experienced support representatives seeking help and advice on how to proceed with difficult problems. This role required strong communication skills as a technical leader and mentor to teach and assist other highly skilled professionals. As part of the role, I defined and author troubleshooting processes, tips, best practices and ongoing technical training. This position was also the first point of escalation beyond Level-1 support. IBM Hardware Technical Support Specialist IBM March 1996  –  July 1998  (2 years 5 months) Raleigh-Durham, North Carolina Area This support position changed my focus to supporting IBM enterprise server hardware. Over time I became an expert with IBM server features, functions, performance, and troubleshooting IBM’s flagship Intel based servers.
